content: quote: Originally posted by staylor101st: Are any of you seeing a run on gun ammo in your areas? In the Houston area many places which sell ammo are sold out. I've got a pretty good stock pile, but hell I like to go the the range 2 or 3 times a month but It's getting to hard to replace the ammo you use. Absolutely. All of my local sporting goods stores are either constantly out or have very little.. ever since about Nov 4th of last year. My advice is to buy all the ammo you can online. That's about the only source from which I've been able to purchase ammo in any significant quantity lately... and even online, many calibers are very scarce. Stack it high and stack it deep, brothers. There are serious stormclouds on the horizon.

content: It's not just a run in this area - check the biggest online suppliers - for example "DirtCheap" - I would say a fair 60% of the links state "out of stock". This has ben going on since after the election... 9 months ago you would have found maybe 200 rounds around my house for my 6 firearms. content: roll yer own... I bought 5 boxes of 50 .45 acp today, three boxes of Monarch and 2 boxes of Aquila, only stuff I could find. I shot one box of Aquila and one box of Monarch and 250 rounds that I reloaded using RNL. The stuff I reloaded shot more accurate than the store-bought stuff! As for the political aspect, Obama and or the Dems have nothing to do with this, it is a supply problem brought on by the Chicken Littles running scared because the NRA and the Obama haters started a rumor that Obama and the Dems were going to take away our guns. When it became obvious that was not true and the supply of guns started catching up with demand, then they decided to make the same claim that Obama and the Dems were after our ammo...now the supply of ammo is critically low...folks are buying every round in sight faster than the dealers can stock it, the NRA membership and contributions have shot up, and that bunch of charlatans along with the gun dealers are laughing all the way to the bank. This gun/ammo thing is the biggest marketing scam since Coca Cola changed its recipe and started that buying spree.

title: Gun Ammo

content: .223, when and where you can find it, has risen an average of 50% - I previously bought a case of 1K federal 55-gr FMJ at 355.00 - good luck finding it under 500 now... I did get lucky yesterday and find deals on 500 rnds for $209, which is still up 30% over 6 months ago. Regarding what is going on here - First, it is true, the military sold once fired brass to the market for like .12 a round - now that brass is required to be scrapped and sold as scrap metal, at pennies on the pound - this accomplished two things - 1) shorts the supply of brass for .223 reloaders, and 2) costs the military millions... Look at the tax recently placed on tobacco products - a carton of smokes went up 7.00 in this area, which was 33% - all tax. It isn't hard to believe that ammo will get hit equally hard - there is no doubting that this administration is going to try to attack the gun market from other-than a head on position - instead of banning the guns, kill the supply of ammo, tax the dog-snot out of it, ban the magazines, and require fire-arms training and liability insurance on every-fire arm owned... People are nervous. Personally, am I 'arming'? No, not yet - but what I am doing is making sure I will have an adequate supply of ammo so my guns don't turn into scrap when we can no onger get ammo and supplies... But I will tell you what, stand in line at a gun show and listen to people...a lot of them aren't stocking up - they ARE arming. The Wal-Mart here can't keep most popular ammunition on the shelves - from .22 up to .45 through 7mm, you just have to be there within hours of them unloading a truck or you are out of luck. I travel a lot, and always check supplies where I go - this is not a local issue... If you are a re-loader, good luck - try to find some dies and primers for the most hard hit calibers - which I would say are: .223/5.56 and 7.62x.39 9mm / .40 S&W / .357 / .45 "All that is necessary for the forces of evil to win in the world is for enough good men to do nothing." --Edmund Burke

content: quote: Originally posted by SFC_Hix_Ret: ...there is no doubting that this administration is going to try to attack the gun market from other-than a head on position - instead of banning the guns, kill the supply of ammo, tax the dog-snot out of it, ban the magazines, and require fire-arms training and liability insurance on every-fire arm owned... BS...this is just plain old BS! quote: People are nervous. Painfully true...but only because of the success of the previous line of politically motivated BS. quote: If you are a re-loader, good luck - try to find some dies and primers for the most hard hit calibers - which I would say are: .223/5.56 and 7.62x.39 9mm / .40 S&W / .357 / .45 There are plenty of used and new dies available on eBay, there are dies, presses, and other reloading supplies available on gunbrokers.com as well as primers, brass, and bullets, and are plentiful and available on gunbrokers.com. However the prices are inflated right now, especially for FMJ bullets and primers. Powder is available, and as long as I can find lead stock, I can make .451 bullets for my .45 acp, but so far, I have not had any trouble finding any cast hard lead RND and SWC .45s which is what I prefer to punch holes with anyway.

content: Skinman, you have that a little skewed. The neocons fully support the taking of arms from the public. It is the regular GOP folks that are stirring up the pot here. I personally don't like anybody trying to outlaw certain weapons. But, it won't effect me anyway, because I won't follow those laws if ever enacted. The only weapon that I have that would fall under the assault weapons ban would be my AR-10. But, I have over 15,000 rounds of 7.62 NATO ammo for a rainy day. I usually use .308 Winchester when I go shooting so as to not deplete my NATO stash. So, I am not too worried.
reply: Skinman, you have that a little skewed. The neocons fully support the taking of arms from the public. It is the regular GOP folks that are stirring up the pot here. content: Cheap .45 acp is running at $20/50 right now locally. That is $0.40 per round. I am reloading hard-cast lead bullets for around $0.19 ~ $0.20 per round, depending on the primer and powder I use, and including the brass at $0.06 per round.
reply: Cheap .45 acp is running at $20/50 right now locally. That is $0.40 per round. I am reloading hard-cast lead bullets for around $0.19 ~ $0.20 per round, depending on the primer and powder I use, and including the brass at $0.06 per round.
title: Gun Ammo

content: quote: Originally posted by skinman13: Cheap .45 acp is running at $20/50 right now locally. That is $0.40 per round. I am reloading hard-cast lead bullets for around $0.19 ~ $0.20 per round, depending on the primer, and powder I use and including the brass at $0.06 per round. Ha, one of the only things I like about you, skinny, is your apparent appreciation for the venerable .45 ACP round. It's my favorite pistol caliber as well. $0.40/round sucks for pistol ammo. Prices have indeed gotten out of hand. Hell I disdain $0.40/round for rifle ammo, (7.62x39mm). This is the reason I haven't taken the Glock 30 to "the range", (lawless adobe hills where I usually go a shootin'), for awhile. It's been cheaper to take the AK out, which is insane. Of course, that'll change as soon as B.O. bans Russian ammo. Oh well, at least the ol 12 gauge is still reasonably cheap to plink with. I'm just glad I did so much training with my Glock 30 last year before The One was coronated... as it'd be a hell of a lot more expensive to do so at today's prices. I plan to sit on the 2k .45 ACP rounds I currently have.
quote: Originally posted by skinman13: Cheap .45 acp is running at $20/50 right now locally. That is $0.40 per round. I am reloading hard-cast lead bullets for around $0.19 ~ $0.20 per round, depending on the primer, and powder I use and including the brass at $0.06 per round.
reply: Ha, one of the only things I like about you, skinny, is your apparent appreciation for the venerable .45 ACP round. It's my favorite pistol caliber as well. $0.40/round sucks for pistol ammo. Prices have indeed gotten out of hand. Hell I disdain $0.40/round for rifle ammo, (7.62x39mm). This is the reason I haven't taken the Glock 30 to "the range", (lawless adobe hills where I usually go a shootin'), for awhile. It's been cheaper to take the AK out, which is insane. Of course, that'll change as soon as B.O. bans Russian ammo. Oh well, at least the ol 12 gauge is still reasonably cheap to plink with. I'm just glad I did so much training with my Glock 30 last year before The One was coronated... as it'd be a hell of a lot more expensive to do so at today's prices. I plan to sit on the 2k .45 ACP rounds I currently have.
title: Gun Ammo

content: Several years ago i had the opportunity to aquire (invest) in precious metals... Lead/Tin/Brass/Antimony of various types. All nicely sealed battle pack bandoleers or neatly boxed. All of these precious metals went into olive drab metal boxes with rubber gaskets and handles... and there they have remained in a temperature controlled environment . Insurance against a day that I knew would come... and here we are. Ammo is scarce as hens teeth in Arizona... particularly in the flavors I require. Expensive as well... but like the ant... I laugh at the grashoppers now scurrying around the empty shelves in the ever encroaching shadow of the Obama boogyman.

content: quote: Originally posted by staylor101st: Are any of you seeing a run on gun ammo in your areas? In the Houston area many places which sell ammo are sold out. I've got a pretty good stock pile, but hell I like to go the the range 2 or 3 times a month but It's getting to hard to replace the ammo you use. The ammo I use (.30-06, 12ga, and .40 cal S&W) are a tad more expensive (50 cents~$1 per box or so) than 6 months ago, but no shortages of those calibers that I've seen. I do a lot of my ammo shopping online or at Academy though. My .40 S&W is still cheaper than my .30-06 - the .40 runs me about $25 for 20rds (180gr) and .30-06 is about $35 for 20 rounds.

content: roll yer own... I bought 5 boxes of 50 .45 acp today, three boxes of Monarch and 2 boxes of Aquila, only stuff I could find. I shot one box of Aquila and one box of Monarch and 250 rounds that I reloaded using RNL. The stuff I reloaded shot more accurate than the store-bought stuff! As for the political aspect, Obama and or the Dems have nothing to do with this, it is a supply problem brought on by the Chicken Littles running scared because the NRA and the Obama haters started a rumor that Obama and the Dems were going to take away our guns. When it became obvious that was not true and the supply of guns started catching up with demand, then they decided to make the same claim that Obama and the Dems were after our ammo...now the supply of ammo is critically low...folks are buying every round in sight faster than the dealers can stock it, the NRA membership and contributions have shot up, and that bunch of charlatans along with the gun dealers are laughing all the way to the bank. This gun/ammo thing is the biggest marketing scam since Coca Cola changed its recipe and started that buying spree.

title: Gun Ammo

content: .223, when and where you can find it, has risen an average of 50% - I previously bought a case of 1K federal 55-gr FMJ at 355.00 - good luck finding it under 500 now... I did get lucky yesterday and find deals on 500 rnds for $209, which is still up 30% over 6 months ago. Regarding what is going on here - First, it is true, the military sold once fired brass to the market for like .12 a round - now that brass is required to be scrapped and sold as scrap metal, at pennies on the pound - this accomplished two things - 1) shorts the supply of brass for .223 reloaders, and 2) costs the military millions... Look at the tax recently placed on tobacco products - a carton of smokes went up 7.00 in this area, which was 33% - all tax. It isn't hard to believe that ammo will get hit equally hard - there is no doubting that this administration is going to try to attack the gun market from other-than a head on position - instead of banning the guns, kill the supply of ammo, tax the dog-snot out of it, ban the magazines, and require fire-arms training and liability insurance on every-fire arm owned... People are nervous. Personally, am I 'arming'? No, not yet - but what I am doing is making sure I will have an adequate supply of ammo so my guns don't turn into scrap when we can no onger get ammo and supplies... But I will tell you what, stand in line at a gun show and listen to people...a lot of them aren't stocking up - they ARE arming. The Wal-Mart here can't keep most popular ammunition on the shelves - from .22 up to .45 through 7mm, you just have to be there within hours of them unloading a truck or you are out of luck. I travel a lot, and always check supplies where I go - this is not a local issue... If you are a re-loader, good luck - try to find some dies and primers for the most hard hit calibers - which I would say are: .223/5.56 and 7.62x.39 9mm / .40 S&W / .357 / .45 "All that is necessary for the forces of evil to win in the world is for enough good men to do nothing." --Edmund Burke

content: Skinman, you have that a little skewed. The neocons fully support the taking of arms from the public. It is the regular GOP folks that are stirring up the pot here. I personally don't like anybody trying to outlaw certain weapons. But, it won't effect me anyway, because I won't follow those laws if ever enacted. The only weapon that I have that would fall under the assault weapons ban would be my AR-10. But, I have over 15,000 rounds of 7.62 NATO ammo for a rainy day. I usually use .308 Winchester when I go shooting so as to not deplete my NATO stash. So, I am not too worried.

content: quote: Originally posted by 15614626: quote: Originally posted by outlaws93: yup wal mart here is sold out of ammo.. i asked about it and they said they sell out as quick as they are resupplied... Went to wal mart today and got the only 2 100rnd boxes of 40sw but they had about 8 50rnd boxes of 50 left for the 40 but they were out of 22-45's only a box or two of hipower ammo as well.Almost baught a 380 at the gun store today but they did'nt have any ammo to feed it so I passed but I may go again on monday if I can get the ammo I'll buy it. Let me guess, they were those Winchester rounds in the white box. I buy those for the range, too. Almost as cheap as reloading.

title: Gun Ammo

content: Cheap .45 acp is running at $20/50 right now locally. That is $0.40 per round. I am reloading hard-cast lead bullets for around $0.19 ~ $0.20 per round, depending on the primer and powder I use, and including the brass at $0.06 per round.
reply: Cheap .45 acp is running at $20/50 right now locally. That is $0.40 per round. I am reloading hard-cast lead bullets for around $0.19 ~ $0.20 per round, depending on the primer and powder I use, and including the brass at $0.06 per round.
title: Gun Ammo

content: quote: Originally posted by skinman13: Cheap .45 acp is running at $20/50 right now locally. That is $0.40 per round. I am reloading hard-cast lead bullets for around $0.19 ~ $0.20 per round, depending on the primer, and powder I use and including the brass at $0.06 per round. Ha, one of the only things I like about you, skinny, is your apparent appreciation for the venerable .45 ACP round. It's my favorite pistol caliber as well. $0.40/round sucks for pistol ammo. Prices have indeed gotten out of hand. Hell I disdain $0.40/round for rifle ammo, (7.62x39mm). This is the reason I haven't taken the Glock 30 to "the range", (lawless adobe hills where I usually go a shootin'), for awhile. It's been cheaper to take the AK out, which is insane. Of course, that'll change as soon as B.O. bans Russian ammo. Oh well, at least the ol 12 gauge is still reasonably cheap to plink with. I'm just glad I did so much training with my Glock 30 last year before The One was coronated... as it'd be a hell of a lot more expensive to do so at today's prices. I plan to sit on the 2k .45 ACP rounds I currently have.

reply: Ha, one of the only things I like about you, skinny, is your apparent appreciation for the venerable .45 ACP round. It's my favorite pistol caliber as well. $0.40/round sucks for pistol ammo. Prices have indeed gotten out of hand. Hell I disdain $0.40/round for rifle ammo, (7.62x39mm). title: Gun Ammo

content: Several years ago i had the opportunity to aquire (invest) in precious metals... Lead/Tin/Brass/Antimony of various types. All nicely sealed battle pack bandoleers or neatly boxed. All of these precious metals went into olive drab metal boxes with rubber gaskets and handles... and there they have remained in a temperature controlled environment . Insurance against a day that I knew would come... and here we are. Ammo is scarce as hens teeth in Arizona... particularly in the flavors I require. Expensive as well... but like the ant... I laugh at the grashoppers now scurrying around the empty shelves in the ever encroaching shadow of the Obama boogyman.
reply: Several years ago i had the opportunity to aquire (invest) in precious metals... Lead/Tin/Brass/Antimony of various types. All nicely sealed battle pack bandoleers or neatly boxed. All of these precious metals went into olive drab metal boxes with rubber gaskets and handles... and there they have remained in a temperature controlled environment . title: Gun Ammo

content: quote: Originally posted by staylor101st: Are any of you seeing a run on gun ammo in your areas? In the Houston area many places which sell ammo are sold out. I've got a pretty good stock pile, but hell I like to go the the range 2 or 3 times a month but It's getting to hard to replace the ammo you use. The ammo I use (.30-06, 12ga, and .40 cal S&W) are a tad more expensive (50 cents~$1 per box or so) than 6 months ago, but no shortages of those calibers that I've seen. I do a lot of my ammo shopping online or at Academy though. My .40 S&W is still cheaper than my .30-06 - the .40 runs me about $25 for 20rds (180gr) and .30-06 is about $35 for 20 rounds.
quote: Originally posted by staylor101st: Are any of you seeing a run on gun ammo in your areas? In the Houston area many places which sell ammo are sold out.
